comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: No Wikipedia entry. From thePeerage.com: Admiral Henry Craven St. John was born on 5 January 1837. (...) He died on 21 May 1909 at age 72. Admiral Henry Craven St. John held the office of Naval Aide-de-Camp to HM Queen Victoria between 1887 and 1889. Notably, he was dead by the beginning of WW1. His son's biography (and rank) is a better match, but the initials don't match. Vice-Admiral Francis Gerald St. John was born on 22 December 1869.1 He was the son of Admiral Henry Craven St. John and Catherine Dora Rodney. (...) He died on 15 February 1947 at age 77. Vice-Admiral Francis Gerald St. John fought in the Boer War. He fought in the Boxer Rebellion in 1900. He fought in the First World War, where he was mentioned in despatches twice. He was invested as a Member, Royal Victorian Order (M.V.O.) in 1914. He was invested as a Companion, Order of the Bath (C.B.) in 1917. He held the office of Aide-de-Camp to HM King George V between 1920 and 1921.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: To judge from cgi.ebay.com/1898-VICE-ADMIRAL-HENRY-CRAVEN-ST-JOHN-NAVY-... this photograph is of Henry Craven, but the original is from earlier than the bulk of the current batch of photos -- taken in Summer 1914.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Arden: the link I provided above is from Navy and Army Illustrated, a British periodical.  Web searches found more photos digitized from the same publication that matched Bain pictures.  FWIW, I see that LC has plenty of volumes of this publication, which might provide better dates for the source image.
